discourse_list.title: [Informal Poll] What does MakerDAO want to see with regard to marketing?

content.content: In Governance and Risk meeting #151, the subject of marketing Core Units came up and conversation has continued in this thread and elsewhere. As a follow-up, Content Production wants to pose a number of questions to the community to encourage conversation around what types of marketing activities the DAO wants to engage in and how the DAO would like to pursue those activities. I think one issue that stands in the way of progress in this conversation is that many of us have different ideas about what “marketing” actually means. In the interest of defining our terms, we’ll share a few of our thoughts on what marketing is and we want to hear from you: what does it mean to you when you talk about “marketing” in the context of the DAO?  What is Marketing? People make decisions based on stories they tell themselves about who they are and how they interact with the world and good marketing is about telling stories that encourage people to make decisions that support organizational goals. In other words, marketing is about helping people find things they want and need; not tricking people into trying things they may or may not care about. Things like tweets, emails, and advertisements are products of marketing and play important roles in context but in a more general context, marketing is about implementing strategies to improve an organization’s relationship with the markets it’s trying to serve. If you have other thoughts or disagree, please leave feedback in the comments.  Feedback If you’re a Facilitator or Contributor of a Core Unit, would you prefer to have a team or coalition of teams you can work with to do marketing or would you prefer to build an in-house team within the Core Unit, or are you considering a different approach? If there’s anything we didn’t mention in the polls you would like to see, please feel free to bring that up as well. The Content team will use the results from these polls to inform our activities and we hope the results can provide value to other teams interested in engaging in marketing activities on behalf of the DAO.  Polls/Questions:    Do you think it would be useful for the DAO to engage in email marketing?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters        Do you think it would be useful for the DAO to engage in press relations?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters        Do you think it would be useful for the DAO to engage in paid advertising on social media?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters        Do you think it would be useful for the DAO to engage in large-scale paid advertising (Stadiums, Commercials, Billboards, etc.)  Yes No Abstain     0 voters        Do you think it would be useful for the DAO to sponsor events?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters        Is it important to you that the DAO has a unified brand?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters

Thank you for the much-needed poll @JerryAG. In my understanding, any marketing effort requires some conception of target customer demographics.  Correct me if I’m wrong but while this might be relatively easy to determine for traditional businesses, it is definitely much harder for one which is crypto-native due to a lack of relevant data? Although I am not sure as to how Maker will solve this problem, I do feel like “general” branding should be unified across all operations except in certain cases where knowledge has been established as to customer demographics (i.e. RWA). I strongly agree that     JerryAG:  marketing is about implementing strategies to improve an organization’s relationship with the markets it’s trying to serve.   Communicating that Maker is ready to serve its market by presenting itself accordingly is paramount. For that, I believe the DAO must learn as much as possible about its actual and target customers.

Seeing Crypto.com in the UFC makes me think that MakerDAO could and should sponsor some sports events like a Premier League team or athlete. It should be a click funnel for using DAI and engaging in DAO governance.
If we had a Dust below 500 DAI I can totally see us being aggressive with advertising and event sponsorship.

ejbarraza:  It should be a click funnel for using DAI and engaging in DAO governance.   What is the process where our name on an athlete gets someone to open a vault? If we got Oasis to put a pop up of “did you find us by seeing our name on an athlete, and if so, who?” on their UI, I would wager large sums of money that no one would provide the name of the athlete we sponsored

NH98:  Communicating that Maker is ready to serve its market by presenting itself accordingly is paramount. For that, I believe the DAO must learn as much as possible about its actual and target customers.   I would agree. I think it is less simple for reasons other than the one you listed;     NH98:  due to a lack of relevant data   For example; because we are a DAO, we also have different products and use cases, therefore different target audiences and marketing needs. The amount of people who are interested in governance, and DAOs, and Vaults, and have the time to keep up with everything happening at Maker is limited at best. Essentially my thought is that it’s easier to breakdown these target customers into the types of interests they have. The unifying part comes in moreso with the branding (including logos, color schemes, font types, styles, cadence, and more) of different content and marketing styles.

MarianoDP:  If we had a Dust below 500 DAI I can totally see us being aggressive with advertising and event sponsorship.   I’d agree the dust limit makes Business-to-Consumer/Customer marketing a bit tenuous. I would add though, I think just having that in mind can have an impact on the types of advertising/events that would be targets for sponsorship. But fair point!

I hear your concern. Frankly I don’t necessarily feel dissimilar. The goal of this post was not to infer that we necessarily should do any of these things, but more so to field community opinions and see where the Humans of MakerDAO feel the best direction would be.

JerryAG:  Humans of MakerDAO feel the best direction would be.   So this is just me taking my own selfish bite of the apple… But I really want to see Maker more socially integrated with the non-crypto world. I know I’m what passes for a Suit around here, but grassroots-style outreach to both society at large and the relevant powers that be strikes me as high return. In my mind, that’s not a billboard or name plastered on something for money, but actual activities that engage people — be it sponsoring financial literacy classes, Solidity coding grants, Q&A with policy makers, or even the capybara vs dragon mascot art contest. Active engagement brings people in the door and wins friends. We need both, and we need it in heaps. It’s a dangerous time to be in 4th place in what is probably a 4-way race to navigate regulations, grow market share, and simply survive. We are far, far, far behind our competitors on this frontier, and marketing needs to focus on quality and depth over quantity and breadth. I’m not a marketing professional. And I hate expenses. But I also know we need marketing for branding and press, even if I am skeptical in it leading to conversions. Maker receives minimal attention and even less respect. A year ago, the Foundation was able to get a call with the OCC. The DAO gets a brusque, dismissive reply that’s not even a form letter. We need advocates and we don’t have them. Whatever their form. MakerDAO doesn’t get to inherit the non-transferable relations that the Foundation had. It will be a monumental task to rebuild them. I hope @Kathleen comes back with something for another round, because we are having to start at the bottom with central banks and media relationships. I don’t know what our marketing plan should be, but I do know we need one. I also know that we won’t know in what direction to push until someone is willing to start a discussion about exactly what direction we should be going. It won’t be pretty. People will be left wanting more. But we need some decisiveness about what Maker is supposed to be and where it should be in 5 years.

PaperImperium:  Maker receives minimal attention and even less respect. A year ago, the Foundation was able to get a call with the OCC. The DAO gets a brusque, dismissive reply that’s not even a form letter.   That’s a bummer but signs of a radically different OCC acting head in comparison with Brooks, who is a crypto champion.
How about advertising on Brave like Sushiswap? This targets the demographic that we want to engage in MakerDAO.

Take a look at this. We already talked to Brave because in the past we tried some campaigns with Oasis without much success. The thing for me is that there is no clear “call to action” or “job to be done”, only branding as “hey use Dai”  image1144×93 6.29 KB   image744×121 5.75 KB   brave.com    Brave_Media_Kit.pdf 8.18 MB         Brave Browser    Transparency Data Feed | Brave Browser This page tracks the growth, development, and ongoing impact of the Brave Rewards program, and the associated Basic Attention Token.      Rates for Ads on the browser as “Background Image” start around 30k per day depending on the target country.

Great thread. I am very hopeful for the discussion this starts and look forward to engaging once I am able to participate as an independent member of the community. Quick question for the group: Is there alignment around the objectives/priorities for MakerDAO? Something that all CUs agree the project is trying to accomplish? As a career-long marketer, I’ve found that information to be critical in determining marketing strategies and tactics that deliver meaningful results. I’ve hammered around forum pages and the community and found bits and pieces (and lots of info about Foundation principles, mission, vision, etc) but not so much about the DAO. Thanks (and apologies in advance if the info is right in front of my face).

It’s a fascinating poll and graphic as the community seems to be quiet divided on strategies, which makes sense why members have different idea of “ideal” marketing strategies. Thanks for bringing this up!
it will be difficult to find equality, but if we achieve it and take advantage of the points on which we all agree, it will be a boom.

I think this poll suffers from ambiguity. I would answer very differently whether Maker is marketing DAI for end users or the Maker protocol for people or orgs that may want to open vaults. The way the poll is worded, this distinction is not made.

Maybe marketing DAI and marketing the products around (vaults, PSM, RWA onboarding) are so entirely different that different marketing CUs might make sense anyway. I was pretty much against marketing anything else then DAI for a long time, but since we suffer on the supply side I am about to switch…

IMO Maker has always needed a good marketing team that bootstraps DAI all over media as lot of other protocols do. Memes, news, hot topics in crypto, is hard to get all these but lot of projects do that, then why Maker no? I always remember Blue Kirby from Yearn, that was like the best marketing thing i’ve seen in crypto, we should be looking things like that, something that makes Maker reach everyone.

MakerMikeP:  Is there alignment around the objectives/priorities for MakerDAO? Something that all CUs agree the project is trying to accomplish?   Currently, my personal answer would be sort of. I think the community generally agrees that growing (in the sense of revenue) the DAO, DAI adoption, and continued innovation are all important in different regards. I think there are a lot of unique perspectives on what we can do as a community in order to achieve those goals, as well as what is the most important. I’d say there are other things some may consider more important as well. So ultimately I think the answer would be no, there is not [currently] a glaring clarity or anything you’re missing (as far as I know).

psychonaut:  I think this poll suffers from ambiguity. I would answer very differently whether Maker is marketing DAI for end users or the Maker protocol for people or orgs that may want to open vaults. The way the poll is worded, this distinction is not made.   I hear your point, personally the goal of this post was not to identify specific objectives as much as community input on what “useful marketing” could look like. Especially when considering the specific outcomes of these processes. Through a lot of forms of marketing, it can be difficult to directly point out the impact aside from things like likes, views, shares, and feedback; which I don’t think necessarily represent the actual impact (especially over time). Absolutely appreciate the feedback. Although it was considered that perhaps this should be less ambiguous, the goal was to target these specific answers opposed to the different nuances of this conversation as a whole. (i.e. start somewhere)

Well, that’s a double edged sword. Don’t you remember Blue Kirby pulled an exit scam and went into hiding and was removed from Yearn?    thedailygwei.substack.com    The Rise and Fall of Blue Kirby - The Daily Gwei #93 The story of how an anonymous Twitter persona went from community darling to community pariah.

Thank you. It’s nice to know I’m not missing something big  It might be a really cool exercise to push people in the community to refine what we want to accomplish, who we want to target to drive growth and what success looks like… it’s not as much fun as suggesting tactics (sports sponsorships, podcast appearances, etc) but with that solid foundation the strategic direction (and tactics) we end up pursuing will be better set up to deliver results that matter for MakerDAO. As noted in my previous post, I am really excited to be a more active participant in the near future. Maybe this is the perfect jumping off point!

Yes, but whether you like it or not, the important thing there is that its mission was achieved and that is to have engagement, to have a voice within the Yearn community and outside it. (apart from the bad things, of course). - MakerDAO needs people from the community that can transmit the values that represent and make Maker special. It’s not just a defi protocol, there are also people behind it, people who can tell a story, who can make Maker more relevant in the space. - (My opinion)

MakerMikeP:  I am really excited to be a more active participant in the near future. Maybe this is the perfect jumping off point!   I think so! I know you’ve been a large part of the marketing team for the foundation, so I think you’ll have lots of good input that will be useful in figuring out what marketing could look like for the DAO. Glad to have you in the conversation!

I agree we need marketing, and dedicated marketing makes the most sense. But we still need to find a balance. A lot can go to waste if we cast the net too wide. It would help to establish who we’re talking to (or want to talk to), understand the problems they have that we can actually address, and then find the channels to talk with them “directly”. Fully in on memes though. Anyone funny?

Doo_StableLab:  Well, that’s a double edged sword. Don’t you remember Blue Kirby pulled an exit scam and went into hiding and was removed from Yearn?   Yeah but leaving aside the bad things you can’t deny he did an amazing job at the beginning.     alec:  I agree we need marketing, and dedicated marketing makes the most sense. But we still need to find a balance. A lot can go to waste if we cast the net too wide. It would help to establish who we’re talking to (or want to talk to), understand the problems they have that we can actually address, and then find the channels to talk with them “directly”. Fully in on memes though. Anyone funny?   Have we thought on a team that coordinates marketing for every CU? This can be also a solution for having marketing inside MakerDAO and not costing too much.
@JerryAG I would like to connect with you. Can you send me a message? I’m relatively new here.
This topic was automatically closed 14 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
